item.title: BMAD v6 Installation Update: Modularization + AgentVibes “talking” dev experience
item.content:encoded:
The core changes in v6 are a rebuilt directory/artifact system plus voice (AgentVibes) formally integrated into the BMAD workflow.

1) Bottom line first: the two most tangible changes from v4 to v6

Section titled “1) Bottom line first: the two most tangible changes from v4 to v6”

Change A: the directory moved from “single core” to an engineering structure of “Core + Modules + Manifests.” In the v4 user guide, personalization preferences (tech stack, naming rules, etc.) were managed at .bmad-core/data/technical-preferences.md.

In v6 (Alpha), the official positioning is “Agent-as-Code + reproducible pipelines,” with an explicit workspace anatomy: .bmad/ stores profiles/blueprints/runs and other traceable artifacts.

Change B: AgentVibes is treated as the first-party experience layer: letting BMAD agents speak in Claude Code, switch voices, and be controlled by slash commands / MCP. AgentVibes’ official description is blunt: it was originally built to “add voice” to Claude Code and offers both MCP (natural-language control) and slash commands.

2) Directory structure: v4 “.bmad-core” vs v6 “.bmad + modules + artifacts”

Section titled “2) Directory structure: v4 “.bmad-core” vs v6 “.bmad + modules + artifacts””

Breaking it down based on the installation log

v4 (common mental model for users)

Section titled “v4 (common mental model for users)”
  • Core directory: .bmad-core/ Stores preferences, data, templates; for example, the v4 user guide clearly points to .bmad-core/data/technical-preferences.md for preferences.
  • Web bundle workflow: dist/teams/... The typical move is to copy dist/teams/team-fullstack.txt into a web UI/Claude/GPT as a “team prompt.”
  • Feels like a “prompt framework + directory convention.” Engineering-wise it works, but “traceable/reproducible outputs” were not the primary goal.

v6 (what your installation shows)

Section titled “v6 (what your installation shows)”

From the log, the most important “on-disk” changes are:

  • Root directory unified at <project>/.bmad (yours: /Users/vsai/.../vs-ai-agents/.bmad)
  • Modular installation: Core + bmb + bmgd + bmm + cis
    • Core: installs core agents (e.g., bmad-master.md)
    • bmb: Builder/Factory (the “factory” for custom agents, workflows, modules)
    • bmm: Method (Analyst/PM/Dev/SM/UX, the full team)
    • bmgd: Game Dev (and vendors cross-module workflows)
    • cis: Creative Innovation Suite

At the same time, it makes a few things explicit that weren’t very visible in v4:

  • Compiles/generates artifacts (manifests): the log literally reports “61 workflows, 21 agents, 5 tasks, 1 tools…” — evidence that v6 is leaning into “versionable/traceable” outputs (much more engineered). That matches the v6 Alpha emphasis on “reproducible, auditable, diffable.”
  • Sprint artifact directory becomes an installation-time setting: you chose docs/sprint-artifacts, and the installer created it (handy for teams running agile).
  • Custom extension directories are explicitly separated
    • bmad-custom-src: custom agents/workflows
    • bmad-custom-modules-src: custom modules
      This essentially forces separation of “official modules” and “custom assets” for easier upgrades/merges.
  • Sidecar memory directory: the log also replaced {agent_sidecar_folder} → {project-root}/.bmad-user-memory (typically for agent “sidecar memory/run traces,” aligning with v6’s artifact-centric approach).

v4 is more “prompt framework + directory convention”; v6 is more “agent engineering system with build artifacts and traceable assets.”

3) AgentVibes integration: the key upgrades from “usable” to “pleasant”

Section titled “3) AgentVibes integration: the key upgrades from “usable” to “pleasant””

The most attention-grabbing part of the log is this:

  • Installer showed “AgentVibes TTS Injection Summary”
  • Injected TTS into .../.bmad/core/agents/bmad-master.md
  • Backups stored at ~/.bmad-tts-backups/
  • Then launched the AgentVibes installer, dropping slash commands, TTS hooks, personality templates, background music, etc., into the project’s .claude/

This matches AgentVibes’ official description closely:

What problem does AgentVibes solve?

Section titled “What problem does AgentVibes solve?”
  • It provides MCP (natural-language control): assistants don’t have to memorize slash commands; you can just say “switch to the Aria voice.”
  • It also provides slash commands (zero token cost) like /agent-vibes:list, /agent-vibes:switch Aria.
  • Multi–TTS-provider abstraction: Piper, macOS Say, ElevenLabs are all supported in the same capability layer (your log shows the macOS Say fast-install path).
  • The installer explicitly states it will put commands/hooks/personalities/plugins into .claude/.

Why does this matter for BMAD v6?

Section titled “Why does this matter for BMAD v6?”

Because v6 targets “multi-agent, multi-workflow, multi-artifact,” humans’ attention gets fragmented across lots of process info. TTS brings two benefits:

  1. Stronger state feedback: start/finish cues are audible — no need to stare at the screen.
  2. Stronger sense of roles: switching PM/SM/Architect/Dev roles feels more like a team (AgentVibes’ BMAD integration highlights this).

4) Summary for moving from v4 to v6

Section titled “4) Summary for moving from v4 to v6”

  1. Plan how to migrate v4 preferences v4 preferences live at .bmad-core/data/technical-preferences.md. v6 emphasizes workspace + policies + manifests (the structure under .bmad/). Recommendation: keep the v4 preference content as “team conventions,” then gradually map it to v6’s profile/policy system (avoid a one-shot forced migration that loses meaning).

  2. Put “custom assets” into the two directories you’ve configured

  • agents/workflows → bmad-custom-src
  • modules → bmad-custom-modules-src
    This reduces conflicts when upgrading v6 alpha/beta later.
  1. Default to “slash commands first” for AgentVibes AgentVibes also notes: MCP is convenient but consumes context tokens; slash commands are cheaper. In other words: use /-commands for daily work, then fall back to natural-language MCP occasionally for a balanced experience and cost.

Detailed log

Section titled “Detailed log”

item.title: Breaking the "No-Device Repro" Challenge: How Antigravity Pinpoints Complex Bugs Through Code Reasoning
item.content:encoded:
Breaking the “No-Device Repro” Challenge: How Antigravity Pinpoints Complex Bugs Through Code Reasoning

Section titled “Breaking the “No-Device Repro” Challenge: How Antigravity Pinpoints Complex Bugs Through Code Reasoning”

In software development, few things frustrate engineers more than this: “the user has a problem, but I can’t reproduce it here.”

Especially when specific hardware, specific user roles, or specific network environments are involved, reproducing the issue often requires pricey devices or complex environment setup. As an intelligent coding agent, Antigravity demonstrates a new approach: without physical devices, use pure code reasoning and full-chain data validation to precisely locate and fix the bug.

This article reviews a recent real case (Issue #181: abnormal records appearing when a doctor views patient data) to walk through this “blind” problem-solving process.

Challenge: An Unseen Site

Section titled “Challenge: An Unseen Site”

Problem description: A hospital doctor unexpectedly saw other patients’ records while using a PC/tablet to view a specific patient’s data.

Difficulties:

  1. No environment: The dev environment cannot connect to the hospital intranet, and cannot log in to that doctor’s account.
  2. No device: The specific device used by the doctor is unavailable.
  3. Limited info: Only one screenshot and a short line: “During rounds, I saw someone else’s data.”

Traditional practice would be: borrow an account, find a device, connect to the intranet, and try to reproduce. If reproduction fails, the bug often gets shelved.

Antigravity’s Problem-Solving Mindset: Logic Over Visuals

Section titled “Antigravity’s Problem-Solving Mindset: Logic Over Visuals”

Antigravity cannot “see” the screen, but it can see through the symptoms to the code essence. The core is three steps: full-chain tracing -> code archaeology -> data falsification.

Step 1: Full-Chain Tracing (UI to Database)

Section titled “Step 1: Full-Chain Tracing (UI to Database)”

Since the UI cannot be operated, read how the UI is built.

  1. Frontend locating: By searching the keyword records.json and analyzing the frontend code patient.service.ts, we quickly pinpointed the API call causing the issue:

    This clarified the direction: doctors use the generic users/records endpoint instead of the doctor-specific one.

  2. Backend tracing: Following the trail into the Rails backend, from UsersController to UserService, and finally down to the core RecordService.

Step 2: Code Archaeology (Finding the Logic Flaw)

Section titled “Step 2: Code Archaeology (Finding the Logic Flaw)”

In RecordService.query_by_user_id_or_patient_id, we found an old snippet that looks “helpful” but is actually dangerous:

Logical reasoning: The comment shows that to accommodate historical dirty data (patient_id of 0), the query forcibly adds 0 to the filter. However, when a doctor (User A) views a patient (Patient B), the system queries: user_id = Doctor_A AND patient_id IN (Patient_B, 0)

This means that as long as there are records under that doctor with patient_id 0 (test data or orphan data that was not bound), they will mix into Patient B’s list.

Step 3: Data Falsification (Nailing the Bug)

Section titled “Step 3: Data Falsification (Nailing the Bug)”

To validate the reasoning, Antigravity did not guess. It wrote SQL to run “probe detection” in the SIT environment (integration test database).

Query 1: Does this doctor actually have “ghost data”?

Query 2: Simulating the bug logic

Query 3: Expected correct logic

Conclusion: Data leakage is real. The extra 2918 rows are exactly those patient_id=0 ghost records being wrongly pulled into Patient B’s page.

Fix and Takeaways

Section titled “Fix and Takeaways”

Once the root cause was found, the fix was obvious: when querying a specific patient (patient_id present), drop the 0 compatibility to keep isolation pure.

This case shows the unique value of an AI agent in software engineering:

  1. Go beyond the surface: Skip UI reproduction; restore business logic through code control flow.
  2. Data-driven: Use direct database access to build test cases that verify hypotheses.
  3. Precision strikes: In millions of lines of code, quickly home in on a few critical conditional checks.

For Antigravity, there is no “unreachable” site; only logic not yet parsed.

item.title: Fixing Bugs Without the User's Phone: An Antigravity Autonomous Debugging Case Study
item.content:encoded:
When a user reports “the lock screen can’t be tapped to enter the app when the phone font is set to maximum,” and you don’t have that phone model on hand, what do you do? This article records how Antigravity, using only the user’s screenshots and description, explored the codebase on its own, reasoned through the issue, and successfully shipped a fix.

Background

Section titled “Background”

In mobile app development, we often hit a tricky situation: a user-reported bug cannot be reproduced in the dev environment. Possible reasons include:

  • No test device of the same model
  • Unable to mirror the user’s specific system settings
  • The issue only appears under a particular combination of conditions

Traditional methods usually require remote debugging, screen-recording analysis, or outright buying/borrowing the device. Now, Antigravity’s autonomous debugging offers a new path.

Problem Description

Section titled “Problem Description”

Issue #169: A user reports that on a certain phone, when the system font is set to maximum, the lock screen cannot be tapped to enter the app.

User-provided information:

  • Device: Samsung Galaxy S20
  • Condition: System font set to maximum
  • Symptom: The “swipe up to enter home” area on the lock screen does not respond

The AI Diagnostic Process

Section titled “The AI Diagnostic Process”

Step 1: Understand the Problem Space

Section titled “Step 1: Understand the Problem Space”

Antigravity first analyzed the key phrases:

  • “font at maximum” -> involves system font scaling (textScaleFactor)
  • “cannot tap” -> likely a layout overflow making the interactive area inaccessible
  • “lock screen” -> need to locate lock screen-related code

Step 2: Code Exploration

Section titled “Step 2: Code Exploration”

The AI used multiple tools in parallel to explore the codebase:

Key findings:

Finding 1: The main app already guards against font scaling

Finding 2: The lock screen is displayed via Overlay

item.title: Decoding Antigravity: An Agentic Workflow from Screenshot to Code Fix
item.content:encoded:
Decoding Antigravity: An Agentic Workflow from Screenshot to Code Fix

Section titled “Decoding Antigravity: An Agentic Workflow from Screenshot to Code Fix”

In the traditional AI-assisted programming (Copilot) model, developers often have to act as “navigators”: you tell the AI “read this file,” “explain this code,” “write a function for me.” Through conversation, you steer the AI to finish the work step by step.

Antigravity represents the next generation of Agentic AI. It is no longer a passive Q&A bot but an “intelligent teammate” that can explore autonomously, reason proactively, and independently complete tasks in complex codebases.

This article uses a real bug-fix case to break down how Antigravity actually works.

1. Perception: More Than OCR (Perception)

Section titled “1. Perception: More Than OCR (Perception)”

Everything starts with user feedback.

Suppose a user submits an issue (e.g., ISSUE-182):

Title: [Weice] blood glucose/uric acid combo meter (a combined glucometer and uric acid analyzer) uploads blood glucose data, but the database does not save it Description: Call POST /api/v2/users/records.json with a payload containing blood_glucose and uric_acid. Checking the database shows only uric acid is stored; blood glucose is missing.

After receiving the task, Antigravity first performs full-context perception:

  • Read the issue description: extract key information (API path, parameter structure, error symptom).
  • Analyze the tech stack: identify it as a Rails API project (backend) plus a Flutter app (frontend).
  • Locate the environment: determine that beyond code, it needs Postgres and Loki MCP servers to check logs and data.

It constructs a “task graph”:

  • Goal: fix the missing uploaded data.
  • Entry point: backend API endpoint /api/v2/users/records.json.

2. Exploration: Reading the code like a senior engineer (Exploration)

Section titled “2. Exploration: Reading the code like a senior engineer (Exploration)”

Antigravity does not guess; it uses its toolchain for purposeful exploration.

Step 2.1 Route locating

Section titled “Step 2.1 Route locating”

It starts like a human engineer, locating the code entry via the API path.

  • Tool Call: grep_search(query: "records", path: "config/routes.rb")
  • Result: finds the route mapped to Api::V2::Users::RecordsController#create.

Step 2.2 Following the trail

Section titled “Step 2.2 Following the trail”

Next, it digs into the controller code.

  • Tool Call: view_file(path: "app/controllers/api/v2/users/records_controller.rb")
  • Analysis: the logic shows it calls a RecordService.new(params).save service class.

Step 2.3 Into the core logic

Section titled “Step 2.3 Into the core logic”

The heart of the problem usually hides in the business layer.

  • Tool Call: view_file(path: "app/services/record_service.rb")
  • Discovery: In RecordService, Antigravity might use view_file_outline to quickly map the method structure and find the data-processing logic:

3. Reasoning: Building a mental model (Reasoning)

Section titled “3. Reasoning: Building a mental model (Reasoning)”

At this point, Antigravity is not just “reading” code; it is running a thought simulation.

Facing the situation where blood_glucose is missing but uric_acid is stored, it quickly proposes several hypotheses:

  1. Hypothesis A: Was blood_glucose filtered out by valid_type?
  2. Hypothesis B: Did a validation error occur during DB write while the main transaction did not roll back?
  3. Hypothesis C: Is there a special filter for the [Weice] device type?

To validate the hypotheses, Antigravity proactively calls MCP tools to query real-time logs or the database:

  • Monitor: use loki_query to inspect API request logs and confirm the payload reached the server.
  • Check DB: use execute_sql to check the records table schema and confirm field definitions.

Combining code logic (static analysis) with runtime state (dynamic analysis), it may spot a line that looks harmless but is the real culprit:

“Aha!” - there is the root cause.

4. Execution: The precise scalpel (Action)

Section titled “4. Execution: The precise scalpel (Action)”

Once the issue is located, Antigravity enters Execution Mode. It is meticulous:

  1. Draft a plan: Antigravity generates an implementation_plan.md listing the files and specific change points.
  2. Request approval: It shows the plan to the user: “I found issue X and plan to modify file Y. Do you approve?”
  3. Perform the edits: After approval, it uses the replace_file_content tool to precisely replace the problematic code block instead of rewriting the whole file.

5. Verification: Not just run, but verify (Verification)

Section titled “5. Verification: Not just run, but verify (Verification)”

Shipping code is not the end. Antigravity knows the importance of testing the main path.

  • Automated tests: It runs rspec spec/services/record_service_spec.rb to ensure the bug is fixed without introducing regressions.
  • Generate a report: Finally, it creates a walkthrough.md with diffs and test-result screenshots to clearly show: “The problem is solved, and here is the evidence.”

Conclusion: From co-pilot to co-worker

Section titled “Conclusion: From co-pilot to co-worker”

Antigravity’s core value lies in agency.

  • It does not need you to feed it every line: give it a requirement, and it finds the relevant files itself.
  • It does not need you to act as its compiler: it runs tests, reads errors, and fixes them itself.
  • It is a closed loop: from discovering the issue to resolving it, it forms a complete workflow.

This is Antigravity - an AI partner that works alongside you, understands code and business context, and is built to solve problems.

item.title: Say Goodbye to Tedious Debugging: Intelligent Troubleshooting with Antigravity + MCP
item.content:encoded:
Say Goodbye to Tedious Debugging: Intelligent Troubleshooting with Antigravity + MCP

Section titled “Say Goodbye to Tedious Debugging: Intelligent Troubleshooting with Antigravity + MCP”

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

As developers, we face a variety of troubleshooting tasks every day: log analysis, database queries, code tracing… these tasks often require switching between multiple tools, consuming lots of time and energy.

This article explains how to use Antigravity (AI coding assistant) together with PostgreSQL MCP and Loki MCP to enable intelligent troubleshooting, making AI your “debugging partner.”

What is MCP?

Section titled “What is MCP?”

MCP (Model Context Protocol) is a standard protocol that connects AI systems to external tools and data sources. Through MCP, AI can:

  • Query databases directly
  • Read logs in real time
  • Analyze system health
  • Execute complex data analysis

We currently have two core MCP servers configured:

  • postgres_api_prod - production database read-only access
  • loki-mcp-server - Grafana Loki log queries

Manual troubleshooting vs AI-assisted troubleshooting

Section titled “Manual troubleshooting vs AI-assisted troubleshooting”

Scenario: Production API responses slow down

Section titled “Scenario: Production API responses slow down”

Manual troubleshooting workflow ❌

Section titled “Manual troubleshooting workflow ❌”

AI-assisted troubleshooting workflow ✅

Section titled “AI-assisted troubleshooting workflow ✅”

Real-world cases

Section titled “Real-world cases”

Case 1: Database health check

Section titled “Case 1: Database health check”

Manual approach: Requires remembering a series of SQL queries, executing them manually, and interpreting the results

AI-assisted approach:

Case 2: Slow-query analysis

Section titled “Case 2: Slow-query analysis”

Case 3: Log analysis

Section titled “Case 3: Log analysis”

Case 4: Index optimization suggestions

Section titled “Case 4: Index optimization suggestions”

Configuration guide

Section titled “Configuration guide”

1. PostgreSQL MCP configuration

Section titled “1. PostgreSQL MCP configuration”

2. Loki MCP configuration

Section titled “2. Loki MCP configuration”

Efficiency comparison

Section titled “Efficiency comparison”
TaskManual timeAI-assisted timeImprovement
Database health check15-20 minutes1 minute15x
Slow-query analysis20-30 minutes2 minutes12x
Log error troubleshooting10-15 minutes1 minute12x
Index optimization suggestions30-45 minutes3 minutes12x
Full issue localization1-2 hours5-10 minutes10x

Best practices

Section titled “Best practices”

1. Describe the problem clearly

Section titled “1. Describe the problem clearly”

2. Provide context

Section titled “2. Provide context”

3. Iterate and go deeper

Section titled “3. Iterate and go deeper”

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Through the combination of Antigravity + MCP, we achieve:

  1. Unified entry point - one conversation interface completes log, database, and code analysis together
  2. Automatic correlation - AI can automatically relate information across different data sources
  3. Intelligent recommendations - not only locates issues but also provides optimization plans
  4. Efficiency leap - troubleshooting time drops from hours to minutes

This is not about replacing traditional tools; it is about making AI your smart assistant to quickly pinpoint issues so you have more time for what truly matters.

Author’s note: This article is based on real-world experience from the API project. If your team is using similar AI coding tools, feel free to share your practices.

item.title: Anthropic Legal Turned Contract Review Drudgery Into a Workflow Art With Claude
item.content:encoded:
Yesterday Anthropic published a new article explaining how their legal team uses Claude / Claude Code to compress work that used to take days into a few hours—while keeping humans in the loop the whole time.

1. Even at a top AI company, legal is still squeezed by grunt work

Section titled “1. Even at a top AI company, legal is still squeezed by grunt work”

Anthropic product counsel Mark described his earlier routine:

  • Replying to compliance documents and customer questionnaires
  • Editing terms of service and privacy policies
  • Reviewing blogs, emails, and marketing assets for the marketing team
  • Redlining contracts and comparing versions line by line
  • Writing a stack of privacy impact assessments (PIA)

These tasks share a few traits:

Repetitive, similar formats, high cost for mistakes, and extremely brain-draining.

He even said many things get pushed to the end of the day because they take so much time yet barely use “the best part of his brain.”

Sound familiar? If you have ever touched legal, compliance, risk, operations, or customer support, you have felt the same pain.

The Anthropic legal team did something very engineer-like:

They held a meeting and wrote on a whiteboard— “What drains the most energy? What repeats the most? What tasks do not deserve this much of our time?”

Once they had answers, they did not rush to “what AI can do.” They focused on a single question:

Which tasks do we never want to do by hand again?

2. How to break down legal workflows: 4 real scenarios

Section titled “2. How to break down legal workflows: 4 real scenarios”

Over a few months, Anthropic’s legal team turned their pain points into repeatable workflows.

1) Self-serve marketing review: AI is the first gate

Section titled “1) Self-serve marketing review: AI is the first gate”

You have surely seen the previous flow:

On the night before launch, marketing would dump landing pages, push copy, and posters on legal: “Please review today; we go live tomorrow.”

Legal had to open the docs -> read end to end -> leave a pile of comments -> go back and forth for multiple rounds. It often dragged on for days.

Anthropic’s rebuild is simple but ruthless:

They built a Self-Review Tool in Slack:

  • Marketing pastes the copy into it

  • Claude calls a dedicated legal Skill file

    • It contains: past review comments, common risk points, and the team’s judgment criteria

  • Claude automatically flags:

    • Exaggerated claims?
    • Is there a source for the data?
    • Any violation of portrait rights or reputation?
    • Any implication of promises that should not be made?

  • Assigns a risk level to each issue: Low / Medium / High

  • Also provides a suggested revision

Only after passing this gate will a ticket be created and enter the legal queue.

StartupHub reported that with this flow, reviews that took days now compress to a few hours, and Slack can auto-generate a summary to help legal see the risk points clearly.

The essence:

Let AI handle the “intake form” and “basic checkup.” The true diagnosis still belongs to the doctor.

2) Side gig / external activity approval: AI asks for details first

Section titled “2) Side gig / external activity approval: AI asks for details first”

Many companies have similar processes:

If an employee wants to moonlight as an adviser, pursue a side business, or serve on a nonprofit board, they must go through “external business activity approval.”

Previously, legal would ask one-on-one about background, conflicts of interest, time commitments, and non-compete risks—going back and forth endlessly.

Here is how Anthropic runs it now:

  • The employee fills out a structured form
  • Claude reads the form
  • If information is missing, it will automatically ask follow-up questions
  • Based on company rules, it provides a recommended decision + risk explanation
  • It then enters the legal queue for an attorney to confirm approval or rejection

Lawyers now mainly focus on two buckets:

  • True edge cases
  • Higher-risk borderline situations

They separated “90% standard flow + 10% extreme judgment.”

3) Privacy impact assessments (PIA): teach AI to write the template

Section titled “3) Privacy impact assessments (PIA): teach AI to write the template”

For privacy projects, every new feature needs a fresh PIA.

The pain:

  • Templates look similar, but you still have to rewrite them each time
  • It must fit the specific scenario without missing required sections

Anthropic’s approach has two steps:

  1. Use MCP (Model Context Protocol) to connect Claude to a Google Drive folder

    • Inside are all historical PIA documents

  2. Equip Claude with a “PIA writing Skill” that spells out:

    • Document structure
    • What to focus on in each section
    • Privacy points the company cares about most

An attorney just says:

“Using the previous cases, draft a PIA for this new feature.”

Claude will:

  • First learn the style of past PIAs
  • Then draft in the same format
  • Transfer historical focus points into the new scenario

The work shifts from “write from scratch” to “edit an 80-point draft.”

4) Legal built a “Morse code lamp,” but the point is that the barrier dropped to human language

Section titled “4) Legal built a “Morse code lamp,” but the point is that the barrier dropped to human language”

There is a fun detail:

Mark used Claude Code to build a “legal desk lamp” that blinks Morse code to send and receive messages—purely a personal hobby project.

But the story highlights something important:

Even a lawyer who cannot code can, by “speaking human language” to AI, build a complete mini app.

For companies, this means:

  • Legal, compliance, and operations—the people who do not code—can build workflows themselves
  • No need to first line up engineering resources or launch a big project
  • As long as they explain the rules clearly, AI can help turn them into tools

It fundamentally changes the belief that “only engineers can build tools.”

3. The building blocks under this legal workflow

Section titled “3. The building blocks under this legal workflow”

Anthropic’s legal system rests on three building blocks:

1) Swap “what tech can do” for “what I refuse to do”

Section titled “1) Swap “what tech can do” for “what I refuse to do””

Mark’s advice is blunt:

Do not start with “what AI can do.” Start with “what work do we most want to escape.”

They followed that approach on a whiteboard:

  • Which documents are repetitive
  • What judgment calls we make every day
  • Which flows can be fully standardized

After confirming, they checked:

  • Can AI do the first pass
  • Reserve human time for disputes, exceptions, and strategic judgment

2) Skills: package team experience into callable assets

Section titled “2) Skills: package team experience into callable assets”

The official blog defines Skills as a document with instructions, scripts, and references that let Claude act like an expert for a task.

For legal, Skills do two things:

  • Keep rules consistent

    • Marketing review Skill: bakes in historical review comments
    • Different domains get different Skills: employment, commercial, privacy, corporate governance…

  • Keep the voice consistent

    • Mark had Claude read 10 of his memos
    • He taught it his structure and tone
    • When Claude drafts memos later, it can “write in his style”

Think of a Skill as:

A senior lawyer’s “plug-in memory card.”

Plug it in when needed; pull it out when you do not.

3) MCP: turn scattered info into a “legal knowledge web”

Section titled “3) MCP: turn scattered info into a “legal knowledge web””

Another key block is MCP (Model Context Protocol).

Anthropic’s legal team connected Claude to:

  • Google Drive: historical contracts, PIAs, templates, policies
  • JIRA: requests and tickets
  • Slack: conversation records
  • Calendar: key meetings and approval checkpoints

This yields two effects:

  • AI stops “hallucinating” because it can check your own materials
  • Each workflow gets just enough context

You can think of it simply:

MCP = connect AI to your “company intranet.”

Skills = teach it “how to use those materials to get work done.”

4. The single most important rule: humans must not be absent

Section titled “4. The single most important rule: humans must not be absent”

Both Anthropic’s blog and the StartupHub article keep repeating: “Legal must stay human-in-the-loop.”

In practice:

  • AI handles:

    • First-pass review and issue spotting
    • Initial risk grading
    • Drafting suggested edits and documents

  • Attorneys handle:

    • Fact-checking and citations
    • Deciding “can the company accept this risk”
    • Final external sign-off

Anthropic is explicit:

AI hallucinates; that is a fact.

So the design is: AI as accelerator, humans as brakes and steering.

For anyone rolling out AI in a company, keep this in mind:

You are not replacing legal with AI. You are using AI so legal stops being a “format fixer and typo hunter.”

5. How teams can “copy the homework”

Section titled “5. How teams can “copy the homework””

After discussing Anthropic, let’s talk about borrowing the idea. Whether you use Claude, ChatGPT, DeepSeek, or your own model, you can follow the same playbook.

Here is how to start:

1) List your team’s “legal hell list”

Section titled “1) List your team’s “legal hell list””

Pick a day and gather legal, compliance, marketing, and product:

  • Write down the tasks you never want to do for the hundredth time
  • Prioritize by “repeatability x risk control”
  • Pick one or two that are ready to pilot now

Typical candidates:

  • First-pass marketing review
  • Standard clause comparison in contracts
  • Data protection and privacy templates
  • Standard questionnaires and compliance Q&A

2) Start with “human + AI dual-layer flow,” then talk automation

Section titled “2) Start with “human + AI dual-layer flow,” then talk automation”

Jumping straight to “end-to-end auto-approval” often dies on risk and trust.

A steadier way:

  • Let AI handle “internal pre-review + draft assistance”

  • Keep the real decision flow unchanged

  • Use one to two months to check:

    • Does it make obvious mistakes?
    • Is speed truly better?
    • Does the team find it more usable?

Once it passes, consider upgrading to:

  • Self-serve tools
  • Workflows wired into internal systems
  • Added templates, Skills, and team norms

3) Feed AI your “rules” and “style” over time

Section titled “3) Feed AI your “rules” and “style” over time”

Follow Anthropic’s two-step method:

  • Rules

    • Compile a “company legal review checklist”
    • For example: banned words, mandatory disclaimers, data points that must be verified
    • Turn it into a long-lived “AI prompt doc” or Skill

  • Style

    • Give AI a few contract reviews or memos your team likes
    • Have it summarize: common structure, phrasing habits, tone preferences
    • Require all future drafts to “follow this style”

Gradually, you will have:

An AI teammate that works the way you do.

4) Do not forget to count the gains

Section titled “4) Do not forget to count the gains”

Is the automation worth it? Anthropic’s “How Anthropic teams use Claude Code” notes that many teams measure efficiency this way, and legal shows especially clear returns.

You can quantify quickly:

  • Average review time per marketing asset
  • Cycle time from “sent to legal” to “legal response” for each contract
  • Hours per week each attorney spends on repetitive documents

Do a before-and-after, and it becomes easy to justify more resources.

6. A quick wrap-up

Section titled “6. A quick wrap-up”

In one line, Anthropic Legal’s practice is:

Use AI as a rules-aware junior assistant to free senior lawyers from grunt work so they can do real judgment.

For anyone who understands the business and a bit of AI, this is a huge opportunity:

  • You can be the person who packages team knowledge into Skills
  • You can build the first “AI + legal workflow”
  • You can turn AI from a “chat toy” into true “process infrastructure”

I am curious:

In your team, what could be handed to AI to handle the groundwork if you follow Anthropic’s approach?

item.title: China AI: 2026 Supply Chain Upside Becomes the Focus
item.content:encoded:
For China’s AI story, this is merely the end of the beginning, and we do not view China’s AI as a bubble. 2025 has been a strong year for China’s AI, sparked by DeepSeek, but from the perspective of supply-chain development, the story is only concluding its opening chapter. We expect total capital expenditures (capex) by Chinese cloud service providers (CSPs) and telecom operators (telcos) to post a 13% compound annual growth rate (CAGR), with AI capex growing at a 25% CAGR to reach USD 172 billion by 2028. Crucially, this spending remains healthy: for listed companies, total capex accounts for only 40%-60% of free cash flow, or about 17% of revenue. The major CSPs have already signaled that they will raise their capex plans, most of which will be allocated to AI, creating USD 88 billion of AI chip demand by 2028.

The domestic supply chain is rapidly scaling to meet this surge in demand. The biggest bottleneck right now is the constraint on domestic advanced-logic capacity, which limits output of local AI chips. However, our channel checks point to a key inflection: advanced-logic capacity should start accelerating in 2026/27 (Figure 12). Given the typical three-to-four-quarter lag from foundry production to AI chip sales, this capacity increase will translate into a sharp rise in domestic AI chip sales in 2027/28 (Figure 14). We estimate domestic AI chip supply in 2028 will be five times 2025 levels, bringing the market into supply-demand balance. Notably, we do not expect NVIDIA to resume sales in China amid the ongoing “backdoor” investigations, so we anticipate domestic players will take over more than 90% of the market by 2028.

The leaders across China’s AI supply chain will benefit. We forecast a broad rebound in 2026 for the entire chain, ranked by industry as: AI chips > semiconductor equipment > foundry.

item.title: Give Claude Long-Term Memory: Hands-on Guide to claude-mem
item.content:encoded:
claude-mem actually lets Claude genuinely “remember you”

Do you ever feel like this:

Every time you open Claude / ChatGPT to write code, you have to re-explain the project from scratch:

“I’m building an admin console, the stack is…” “Last time we stopped at user login; this time we need to add…”

Halfway through explaining, you’re already annoyed.

The model isn’t dumb; it just has no memory.

Today, let’s look at a fun little GitHub project: claude-mem—a “long-term memory” add-on for Claude Code.

1. What exactly does claude-mem do?

Section titled “1. What exactly does claude-mem do?”

In one sentence:

It automatically records what you do in Claude Code, summarizes and compresses it, and the next time you open the same project, Claude will “actively recall” past context.

More specifically, it is:

  • A Claude Code plugin
  • Automatically captures: your prompts, tool calls, file reads/writes, etc.
  • Uses Claude’s Agent SDK in the background to summarize and extract key points
  • Stores them in a local database and vector store; supports full-text + semantic search
  • When you reopen Claude Code, it injects the most relevant history back into the new conversation automatically

So the experience is:

You keep coding, and Claude becomes the partner who remembers the project background even better than you do.

2. How does it give Claude “memory buffs”?

Section titled “2. How does it give Claude “memory buffs”?”

The official README has a clear flowchart; here’s the plain-language version:

1) Session start: feed it “recent events”

Section titled “1) Session start: feed it “recent events””

Each time you start a new session in Claude Code, claude-mem digs out “recent key info” from the database, organizes it into a concise context block, and injects it automatically at the top of the conversation.

It’s like running through, in your head, before meeting a friend:

“Last time we talked about login and signup—what pitfalls did we hit?“

2) While you code: it quietly takes notes

Section titled “2) While you code: it quietly takes notes”

Throughout the development session, it keeps recording:

  • Important prompts you send to Claude
  • The “observations” from Claude’s tool calls (which files were read, what was written)
  • Some critical intermediate steps

These raw snippets are not replayed wholesale as context. Instead, they’re sent to the Worker Service, which uses Claude’s Agent SDK to summarize:

“What are the takeaways worth remembering from this session?”

For example:

  • We decided to drop a certain third-party library
  • Refactored the interface design of a module
  • Fixed a nasty bug and summarized its root cause

3) Session end: generate a “study note”

Section titled “3) Session end: generate a “study note””

When the session ends, it does one more thing:

Condenses the entire session into a “project changelog + decision digest.”

That gets stored in local SQLite (for full-text search) while also being written to a vector database like Chroma for semantic search.

Next time Claude looks up history, it won’t rummage through everything. It uses smart search + progressive disclosure to inject a small but crucial slice of context back into the chat.

3. What’s in it for developers?

Section titled “3. What’s in it for developers?”

1) Long-running projects: no more endless recaps

Section titled “1) Long-running projects: no more endless recaps”

Picture a real scenario.

You’re building a SaaS admin console over 3 months, constantly interrupted by meetings and changing requirements.

Without claude-mem, every return to the project looks like this:

  • Skim Git logs and docs first
  • Paste a long prompt to explain the background to Claude
  • Only then does Claude get into the groove

With claude-mem installed:

  • As soon as a new session opens, Claude already knows:

    • What the project is about
    • Which modules changed recently
    • Which pitfalls you’ve hit so you don’t repeat them

You only need to say:

“Pick up where we left off on permissions and finish the export feature.”

Claude can “follow the thread” instead of looking lost.

2) mem-search: a “project time machine”

Section titled “2) mem-search: a “project time machine””

claude-mem also ships a neat skill: mem-search.

You can ask it in natural language:

  • “Find how we designed the login API before.”
  • “That file upload bug—how did we fix it back then?”

Unlike a basic code keyword search, mem-search looks through conversations + tool calls + summarized knowledge, and lets you control how much context to inject via progressive disclosure, saving tokens.

Simply put:

It turns “I vaguely remember we discussed this” into “I can surface it on demand.”

3) Web UI: see what Claude is “thinking” in real time

Section titled “3) Web UI: see what Claude is “thinking” in real time”

The project provides a Web Viewer at http://localhost:37777 by default:

  • Watch the current session’s “memory stream” in real time

  • Search history

  • Check exactly what got recorded and what will be injected

For privacy-conscious teams, this matters a lot. You can visually confirm whether anything sensitive was stored.

4) Privacy control: block with a tag

Section titled “4) Privacy control: block with a tag”

If you have sensitive content (internal systems, secrets, user data), wrap it in <private> and claude-mem will exclude it from persistence.

The model can still use that info within the current session, but it won’t be written into long-term memory, reducing leakage risk.

That’s a nice plus for compliance-focused orgs.

4. How to install? Is it hard?

Section titled “4. How to install? Is it hard?”

The author made installation match Claude Code habits closely.

In Claude Code’s terminal, open a new session and run two lines:

Restart Claude Code and it starts working automatically.

More advanced (optional) moves:

  • Run the local worker service and Web UI
  • Tune configs (what to record, token strategy, etc.)
  • Customize settings or integrate with more complex environments

For most developers, the default setup is already great. Once you’re hooked, explore docs on “Context Engineering” and “Progressive Disclosure” later.

5. Who is it for? Any pitfalls?

Section titled “5. Who is it for? Any pitfalls?”

Best suited for

Section titled “Best suited for”

These groups will feel the biggest gains:

  • Lead developers on long projects If you spend a year on one big project, you’ll love it.

  • People who rely on Claude Code as their primary IDE helper Daily AI pair programming makes memory benefits obvious.

  • Side project / open-source enthusiasts If you pause for a week or two, you can still “resume seamlessly.”

Maybe less critical

Section titled “Maybe less critical”
  • Just occasionally asking Claude to write a small script
  • One-off experiments or single-file utilities

At that intensity, claude-mem’s long-term memory edge is minor—install it if you feel like it.

Potential pitfalls

Section titled “Potential pitfalls”
  • Requires running a local daemon and database
  • Team use needs data storage and access policies
  • It’s a community project; you need to watch upgrades and compatibility

That said, judging by stars and activity, the community is healthy. If you hit issues, open an Issue and discuss.

6. A pragmatic ROI view

Section titled “6. A pragmatic ROI view”

From a time/money perspective, claude-mem pays off mainly by:

  • Saving time No more repeating project context or digging through old chats.

  • Reducing mistakes Avoid re-hitting old pitfalls; remember prior decisions.

  • Stabler collaboration When projects pause or team members change, history is easier to restore.

If you’re already paying for Claude / GPT, every “re-explaining the project” burns tokens. claude-mem essentially helps you:

Turn “explaining repeatedly” into “explain once, reuse many times.”

Summary: make AI the “teammate with great memory”

Section titled “Summary: make AI the “teammate with great memory””

For many people, AI is now essential to daily development. But an AI without memory is more like a short-term intern:

  • Capable in the moment
  • Limited long-term project value

A “memory add-on” like claude-mem upgrades it into a long-term teammate who truly understands the project context.

If you’re already coding with Claude Code, set aside an hour on the weekend to install it and try:

You might suddenly realize— the real ceiling of LLMs isn’t “how much code they write,” but “how much of the journey they can remember.”

Question to ponder

Section titled “Question to ponder”

How are you making AI “remember projects” today?

  • Handwritten docs?
  • Copy-pasting giant prompts each time?
  • Or simply giving up and letting it remember whatever it can?

Share your approach in the comments, or how you’d use claude-mem for your projects.

item.title: Decoding the AI Chip Wars: Why Google TPU Won't Kill NVIDIA
item.content:encoded:
Decoding the Real AI Chip War

Section titled “Decoding the Real AI Chip War”

Lately the market’s favorite storyline goes like this:

“Google TPU is rising, NVIDIA is about to be taken out; AWS has Trainium, Microsoft has Maia, in-house ASICs will push GPUs off the throne.”

But if you look at Morgan Stanley internet analyst Brian plus semiconductor analyst Joe Moore’s kind of “inside view,” and cross-check the public data, a picture closer to the industry’s real logic emerges:

This isn’t about “who replaces whom”—it’s “if it can compute, we want it.” In the short run it’s compute scarcity; in the long run profits concentrate with the few who control standards and cost.

I’ll frame this article around four questions:

  1. Have we really entered an “infinite compute era”?
  2. Whose normal is multi-architecture coexistence—the giants, or the whole industry?
  3. Google has TPU, so why can’t it ditch NVIDIA?
  4. How should regular investors choose in this “everyone is building chips” melee?

Along the way I’ll weave in:

  • Fact checks on each point (at least 3 professional sources cross-verified),
  • Logic breakdowns,
  • And some perspective on “who is selling what story” from the standpoint of incentives and human nature.

I. Compute Flood: “Never Enough” or “Shortage for Now”?

Section titled “I. Compute Flood: “Never Enough” or “Shortage for Now”?”

1. How much of a “flood”? Start with some hard numbers

Section titled “1. How much of a “flood”? Start with some hard numbers”

(1) Data center CapEx is exploding

  • Dell’Oro reports: in 2024 Q2, global data center capital expenditure rose 46% YoY, driven mainly by deployments of AI accelerator servers (GPU / TPU / in-house accelerator cards).
  • Same firm later tallied: full-year 2024 global data center CapEx jumped to $455 billion, up 51%, with 2025 still expected to post double-digit growth, powered chiefly by AI accelerator servers.

These numbers are basically saying:

“Everyone is spending on data centers at a historically rare speed—and it’s specifically for AI.”

(2) On the GPU side: NVIDIA as an “income black hole”

  • NVIDIA’s latest earnings: FY2025 Q4 (through 2025-01-26) revenue of $39.3 billion for the quarter, +78% YoY, mainly from data center.

  • Industry estimates: in FY2025 Q3, NVIDIA’s data center segment alone topped $50 billion in a single quarter, with gross margin near 75%.

  • For the “data center GPU” market by itself, research firms estimate: about $10.5 billion in 2025, with potential to expand to $77 billion by 2035, >22% CAGR.

(3) Blackwell’s real state: not “no one wants it” but “nowhere near enough supply”

NVIDIA management repeatedly stressed across late 2024 and 2025 earnings calls:

  • Hopper and Blackwell platforms are both supply-constrained;
  • Blackwell demand is expected to “exceed supply” for multiple consecutive quarters in FY2026, with much of next year’s capacity already pre-booked.

Most research reports and media agree:

High-end AI GPUs (H100/H200/Blackwell) are in “line up and rationing” mode.

So your original line:

“The game isn’t about chip architectures, it’s about whether you can get cards”

is consistent with public data in the near-term 1–3 year window.

2. But “compute is forever scarce” is a feeling, not a law of physics

Section titled “2. But “compute is forever scarce” is a feeling, not a law of physics”

That nuance matters for investors.

(1) Physical and infrastructure constraints

  • AI data centers aren’t just about buying cards; you also need:

    • Power: large AI facilities routinely draw hundreds of megawatts;
    • Copper and materials: analyses show AI data centers use 27–33 tons of copper per MW. At current project plans, existing and in-progress copper mines would cover only about 70% of demand by 2035, with a potential 300,000-ton shortfall as soon as 2025.

These constraints are a reminder:

“Infinite compute” is a demand-side wish—the real world applies brakes via the grid, materials, and permits.

(2) Cash flow and shareholder constraints

  • Cloud providers now spend tens to hundreds of billions of dollars annually on AI infrastructure,
  • But shareholders ask: “How fast do these GPUs/TPUs pay back? Are AI products earning enough?”

If over the next two to three years “big-model monetization” lags market expectations, CapEx growth will inevitably fall from 50%+—just like any prior infrastructure cycle (4G, cloud, fiber).

Bottom line on this point:

  • Facts:

    • Right now we truly are in a phase of compute scarcity + acute high-end GPU shortage;

  • Opinion:

    • “Compute is forever insufficient” is an emotion amplified;

  • Investment meaning:

    • Short term you can justify valuations with “card-hoarding logic”;
    • Medium to long term you must watch when power / materials / ROI start cutting growth—the three blades of the scissors.

II. “Whoever has compute, we use”: Multi-architecture Is a Survival Move, Not a Pretty Choice

Section titled “II. “Whoever has compute, we use”: Multi-architecture Is a Survival Move, Not a Pretty Choice”

Your second takeaway was:

“Right now I’ll use any compute I can get. NVIDIA, AMD, in-house ASICs, TPU, even the next cheap chip—I’ll buy.”

Let’s see what parts of that line up with reality and which are privileges of the very top tier.

1. The facts: top players truly are running “multi-architecture”

Section titled “1. The facts: top players truly are running “multi-architecture””

(1) The hyperscaler structure

Multiple research shops (Kearney, MLQ.ai, etc.) in 2025 reports note:

  • The data center AI accelerator market is still dominated by NVIDIA,
  • But Google TPU, AWS Trainium, Microsoft Maia and other in-house chips are expected to reach 15–20% internal deployment share in the late 2020s (mostly their own workloads).

In other words:

  • For Google/AWS/Microsoft and peers:

    “GPU + in-house ASIC mix” is already written into the roadmap as reality.

(2) How specific vendors do it

  • Google Cloud: AI Hypercomputer

    • On one side it’s rolling out the new Trillium TPU (6th gen),
    • On the other it explicitly says in the official blog it will include NVIDIA Blackwell platforms (B200 / GB200) as part of Hypercomputer, letting customers pick between TPUs and NVIDIA GPUs.

  • AWS: Trainium + NVIDIA GPU sold side by side

    • At re:Invent 2024/2025, AWS launched Trainium2/3/4 in-house AI chips and UltraServer, pitched as “cheaper training + inference compute”;

    • Meanwhile, its compute-track tech blog stresses:

      “Our accelerated compute lineup includes both GPU instances and AWS AI chip instances; customers choose based on cost / performance / compatibility.”

  • Microsoft: Maia for inside, NVIDIA for customers

    • Microsoft introduced Maia 100/200 AI accelerators, clearly for internal mega-model workloads like its own and OpenAI’s;
    • At the same time Azure keeps deploying and touting the latest NVIDIA GPUs (including GB300 NVL72 clusters), with joint blogs on “extracting every drop of value from every GPU on Azure.”

All this shows:

In the very top circle, “multi-architecture coexistence” is already fact. They literally practice your line: “whoever can deliver compute, we use.”

2. But this isn’t the industry’s default—it’s a giant’s privilege

Section titled “2. But this isn’t the industry’s default—it’s a giant’s privilege”

The logical trap is:

Seeing frontier model shops run 4–5 architectures and assuming every AI company can do that.

Reality is closer to:

  • Only cloud giants / top model companies can afford to:

    • Maintain multiple hardware stacks (GPU / TPU / Trainium / Maia / other ASICs);
    • Spend engineering to port models across backends (CUDA, ROCm, XLA, in-house SDKs);
    • Build unified scheduling / compilation / MLOps layers to mask heterogeneity.

  • Most AI startups and enterprise customers behave more like:

    “As long as I can rent enough NVIDIA GPUs, I won’t deliberately tinker with other architectures.”

Ecosystem proof points:

  • CUDA still enjoys much broader framework, toolchain, tutorial, and open-source support than any other stack;
  • When third-party training/inference platforms do “multi-backend support,” they still default to NVIDIA as first priority.

So:

  • Your line “multi-architecture became the norm” is

    • True for Google/AWS/Microsoft/OpenAI/Anthropic;
    • For typical AI companies, it’s more “NVIDIA first, others as backups.”

3. Incentives: who is gaming whom behind multi-architecture?

Section titled “3. Incentives: who is gaming whom behind multi-architecture?”

Pull this back from “technical pluralism” to “incentive reality”:

  • For big model firms / cloud providers, the real motives are three:

    1. Survival: during compute shortages, “whoever has cards is your lifesaver”;
    2. Price pressure: use TPU / Trainium / Maia to lean on NVIDIA in negotiations;
    3. TCO: shift some inference loads to cheaper, more efficient ASICs to lower long-run costs.

  • For NVIDIA, the prime goal is:

    “Make CUDA + platform ecosystem the default industry standard, so even if others ship cheaper chips, migration costs stay high.”

Conclusion:

Multi-architecture isn’t “the beauty of technical diversity”— it’s a supply-chain, cost, and bargaining-power game.

III. Google Has TPU—Why Still Buy NVIDIA?

Section titled “III. Google Has TPU—Why Still Buy NVIDIA?”

Your third point hits the mark:

“Google has TPU yet keeps buying NVIDIA GPUs—TPU supplements, not replaces.”

That’s squarely in line with public info.

1. What Google itself says

Section titled “1. What Google itself says”

  • Google Cloud’s blogs and docs state plainly:

    • AI Hypercomputer includes in-house Trillium TPU,
    • And NVIDIA H200 / Blackwell (B200, GB200 NVL72) GPU instances,
    • Customers can choose different accelerator mixes as needed.

  • Many Google customer stories mention using both TPU and NVIDIA GPU:

    • Some training jobs run on TPU,
    • But latency-sensitive or CUDA-native workloads stay on GPU.

2. Why not “TPU only”?

Section titled “2. Why not “TPU only”?”

(1) Business mix differences

  • Core internal businesses (search, ads, YouTube recommendations, GWS, etc.):

    • Can be forced onto TPU on Google’s own timeline—this is “internally controlled + long-term ROI.”;

  • For the external cloud business:

    • Customers have mountains of CUDA-based code, models, and tooling;
    • If Google said “TPU only, no GPU option,” it would shove customers to AWS/Azure.

So for Google, GPU and TPU split is:

  • TPU: mass internal production + some external, focused on lowering its own long-run compute costs;
  • NVIDIA GPU: ecosystem default + customer demand, essential for keeping cloud clients.

(2) Path dependence and migration costs

Even if TPU is cheaper or more efficient for certain tasks, for most developers already “trained by CUDA”:

“Rewrite tons of code + rebuild the entire toolchain” costs more than “pay a bit of NVIDIA tax.”

3. In the bigger picture: what in-house ASICs really do

Section titled “3. In the bigger picture: what in-house ASICs really do”

Across Google TPU, AWS Trainium, Microsoft Maia public statements, a more grounded conclusion is:

  • In-house ASICs are tools for giants to “lower long-run compute costs + secure supply chain”;

  • They’re not meant to “sell so much on the open market that NVIDIA dies”;

  • They’re leverage to say at the bargaining table:

    “I’m not forced to use your cards; I can make my own—keep prices reasonable.”

So your line—“TPU is a complement, not a replacement”— holds perfectly at the industry-structure level.

IV. “Infinite Compute, Everyone Wins”?—The Retail Investor Trap

Section titled “IV. “Infinite Compute, Everyone Wins”?—The Retail Investor Trap”

Your vivid wrap-up was:

“All architectures and vendors get pulled into the same black hole—racing for time, cards, iteration speed. GPU, TPU, ASIC aren’t substituting but expanding together; the winners are anyone who can supply compute.”

The direction is right:

  • Right now “anyone who can deliver high-performance compute has business”;

But for investors, the key question is:

Business ≠ high profit, and certainly not that everyone makes big money.

1. Profit pools are highly concentrated—not “rain for all”

Section titled “1. Profit pools are highly concentrated—not “rain for all””

From current data:

  • NVIDIA:

    • Single-quarter data center revenue ~$50 billion, gross margin about 75%—classic “money-printing”.

  • Other vendors (including some GPU/ASIC makers):

    • Revenue ranges from hundreds of millions to low billions;
    • Gross margins, pricing power, and ecosystem stickiness nowhere near NVIDIA.

Consensus view:

The AI accelerator profit pool is highly concentrated in a handful of leaders; Many others have revenue and a story, but not necessarily fat margins.

For retail investors, the “everyone wins” narrative is dangerous—it nudges you to buy a basket of fringe players, while the real money may accrue only to those with standards + ecosystem + cost curve control.

2. In-house ASIC as a long-term threat—who feels it first?

Section titled “2. In-house ASIC as a long-term threat—who feels it first?”

In-house chips don’t “instantly slay NVIDIA”; they gradually reshape who captures how much profit.

  • For NVIDIA:

    • Short term: still the prime beneficiary; all clouds are still frantically buying its cards;
    • Medium/long term: once TPU/Trainium/Maia reach 15–25% internal share at each cloud, they’ll start chipping away at NVIDIA’s ultimate pricing power (the dreaded “GPU tax”).

  • For second-tier / smaller chip vendors:

    • Squeezed from above by in-house ASIC price pressure, from below by NVIDIA’s ecosystem moat;

    • They sit in the most painful spot—

      “A bit less performance, far weaker ecosystem, and not cheap enough to be irresistible,”

    • Many could be the first out in the elimination round.

So:

The bullets from in-house ASICs may not hit NVIDIA first; they may land on the tier lacking ecosystem, scale, and cost advantage.

3. Three blades against the “infinite compute” story: power, capital, regulation

Section titled “3. Three blades against the “infinite compute” story: power, capital, regulation”

One more time: compute cannot truly expand without limit:

  1. Power and materials:

    • AI data centers compete with society-wide energy infrastructure for power, transformers, copper, and cooling;
    • Long-cycle copper supply has been flagged to tighten further around 2030.

  2. Return on capital:

    • If AI app monetization lags CapEx spending,
    • Shareholders will force clouds to slow the “spend curve,” directly braking upstream chipmakers.

  3. Policy and regulation:

    • Energy use, carbon, data center siting, AI risk rules—once scaled, these become hard constraints;
    • They’re in the brewing stage now; once enacted, they immediately affect compute expansion pace.

V. How Can Individual Investors Use This?

Section titled “V. How Can Individual Investors Use This?”

To compress the above into a usable investment framework, I’d give readers a few rules:

1. Don’t get dragged by “who replaces whom” plots

Section titled “1. Don’t get dragged by “who replaces whom” plots”

  • Near term:

    • NVIDIA remains the AI compute center;
    • TPU / Trainium / Maia mostly serve giant internal needs.

  • Long term:

    • Watch not “are there new players,” but “who controls the standard (software ecosystem) and cost curve.”

2. Slice the industry into three layers—not one big stew

Section titled “2. Slice the industry into three layers—not one big stew”

Roughly split into three:

  1. Compute chip/module providers

    • NVIDIA, AMD, in-house ASICs (TPU / Trainium / Maia), some new-arch players;

    • Those likely to earn thick profits long run are the few with:

      • Ecosystem (CUDA/platform/middleware),
      • Scale (volume + supply-chain control),
      • Cost advantage (process + packaging + efficiency).

  2. Compute infrastructure providers

    • Clouds (AWS / Azure / GCP, etc.), data center operators, power and cooling solution vendors;
    • They feast on CapEx demand while bearing “payback pressure” and policy risk.

  3. Compute “upstream applications”

    • Big model firms / AI SaaS / vertical AI apps;
    • They determine whether these GPUs/TPUs turn into sustained, meaningful cash flow.

3. Flag two common pitfalls for readers

Section titled “3. Flag two common pitfalls for readers”

  1. “AI concept stocks rain on all” trap

    • Seeing everyone build chips/AI and assuming all stocks get equal upside;
    • In reality profits concentrate—bad picks hurt more than missing the sector.

  2. “Forever shortage” emotional trap

    • When everyone shouts “cards are never enough, compute is forever scarce,” ask:

      “In which year do supply/power/regulation flip from ‘shortage story’ to ‘price pressure, expansion slowdown’ reality?”

VI. One-Line Summary of the Real Industry Logic

Section titled “VI. One-Line Summary of the Real Industry Logic”

Compressing everything into one line for readers:

This isn’t a “TPU vs. NVIDIA vs. Trainium” winner-take-all; it’s a systemic war over who can control high-performance compute + software ecosystems + cost curves for the long haul.

In the short run, anyone who can reliably ship top-tier compute can gorge on the flood of demand; over the long run, profits concentrate with the very few who have ecosystem, scale, and cost advantages.

For regular investors, instead of staring at “who replaces whom” soundbites, calmly watch three things:

  1. Whose product is the industry’s “default option”? (standards & ecosystem)
  2. Who lowers cost per unit of compute fastest? (cost curve)
  3. Who can survive the post-CapEx-peak “rational return” phase? (business model & cash flow)

item.title: Google Antigravity Can Code and Draw: One-Click UI and Image Generation in Your IDE
item.content:encoded:
Straight to the point: Google Antigravity, this new IDE, doesn’t just write code — it can “casually draw” inside the editor. UI sketches, logos, and marketing images are all one click away.

I. What on Earth Is Antigravity? Why Are Engineers Talking About It?

Section titled “I. What on Earth Is Antigravity? Why Are Engineers Talking About It?”

In short:

Antigravity = VS Code look + multi-agent AI core + Gemini 3 Pro + built-in image generation

It’s Google’s AI-first (agent-first) development platform that runs a fleet of AI agents across the editor, terminal, and built-in browser to help with planning, coding, testing, and demoing. ([Google Developers Blog][1])

Antigravity is currently in free public preview, supports Windows / macOS / Linux, uses Gemini 3 Pro by default, and can also connect to Claude Sonnet 4.5 and some open-source models. ([Wikipedia][2])

For those of us building frontends, product demos, or side projects, it’s basically:

Opening the IDE = opening a “studio with an artist and a helper”

II. How Do You “Draw” Inside Antigravity? Which Models Power It?

Section titled “II. How Do You “Draw” Inside Antigravity? Which Models Power It?”

1) Two built-in image models: Imagen 3 + Nano Banana Pro

Section titled “1) Two built-in image models: Imagen 3 + Nano Banana Pro”

According to official notes and community feedback, image generation in Antigravity now follows two main tracks: ([Google Antigravity][3])

  • Default: Imagen 3
    Used for generating illustrations and supporting images inside the IDE; general-purpose creation.

  • Advanced: Nano Banana Pro (Gemini 3 Pro Image)
    Google’s new image model, offering:

    • Clearer text rendering (no more blurry English copy on posters)
    • More complex logic and layouts (charts, infographics)
    • Higher resolutions (1K / 2K / 4K output)
    • Multiple reference images for consistent style/composition

Official blogs and docs say Nano Banana Pro is already integrated into Antigravity, so you can call it directly inside the IDE to generate UI mockups, logos, marketing graphics, and more. ([Google Antigravity][3])

2) Image generation isn’t a standalone toy—it’s part of the workflow

Section titled “2) Image generation isn’t a standalone toy—it’s part of the workflow”

InfoWorld’s hands-on review mentions that Antigravity’s agents can directly call Nano Banana to create UI mockups and image assets. ([InfoWorld][4])

Typical scenarios include:

  • Generate several UI sketches for a new page
  • Produce logo options for a product
  • Create illustrations/visuals for a marketing page
  • Auto-generate diagrams or visuals for docs

Interestingly, one tester hit a situation where image services were overloaded and the agent failed to generate images for a while. It immediately “switched strategies” and wrote an entire HTML/CSS page as the mockup instead. That’s the agent workflow in action:

“Either I’ll give you images, or I’ll give you a runnable frontend page.”

III. What Real Value Does This Bring to Frontend, Product, and Indie Makers?

Section titled “III. What Real Value Does This Bring to Frontend, Product, and Indie Makers?”

1) A “write requirements while generating images” dev experience

Section titled “1) A “write requirements while generating images” dev experience”

A real user on Reddit shared:

Building an RV rental site needed six hero images for popular destinations.
They simply asked the agent inside Antigravity to generate the right photos and auto-apply them to card components—done in about one minute. ([Reddit][5])

This flips the traditional flow:

Before: finish the page → open stock sites/design tools → download/export → drop back into the project
Now: one line in the IDE → images + code land together

For MVPs, hackathons, and internal demos, “finding/making images” now compresses into minutes.

2) The wall between UI design and implementation gets thinner

Section titled “2) The wall between UI design and implementation gets thinner”

Antigravity agents package generated images, mockups, and code changes into Artifacts (deliverables), so you can: ([Google Antigravity][6])

  • View mockups side by side with code diffs
  • Comment directly on Artifacts: “Make the button larger”, “Switch the primary color to blue”
  • Ask the agent to revise images and code based on that feedback

This also smooths collaboration:

  • Product/Design: leave natural-language comments on the Artifact page
  • Dev: focus on diffs and logic
  • Agent: runs errands—edits images and code

3) Solo founders: one IDE equals a small team

Section titled “3) Solo founders: one IDE equals a small team”

If you’re building alone:

  • Copywriting: have the model draft your landing page
  • Design: ask Antigravity for illustrations, UI mockups, logo drafts
  • Development: use the same agent to drop images into the frontend and even scaffold API/backend

Essentially:

Opening Antigravity = hiring a copywriter, an artist, and a junior engineer
You just play director and decision-maker

IV. What Does It Actually Take to Generate an Image Inside Antigravity?

Section titled “IV. What Does It Actually Take to Generate an Image Inside Antigravity?”

Based on Google’s official Codelab and several tutorials, the flow looks like this: ([Google Codelabs][7])

Below is a typical “image + frontend code” play to help you picture it.

Step 1: Create a task and ask the agent for a page plus visuals

Section titled “Step 1: Create a task and ask the agent for a page plus visuals”

In Agent Manager, create a Task, e.g.:

“Build a landing page for a fitness app, including a hero section, and generate a hero illustration for the top of the page.”

The agent will automatically:

  • Plan the task (generate a Task Plan)
  • Decide which files and images are needed
  • Create/modify code files in the editor

Step 2: Call the image model to produce visuals

Section titled “Step 2: Call the image model to produce visuals”

During execution, the agent will call the built-in image models:

  • Default is Imagen 3
  • If you follow the tutorial scripts, you can also route through Nano Banana Pro (Gemini 3 Pro Image) for more complex, text-heavy designs ([Zenn][8])

It shows a set of image candidates in the Artifact panel:

  • Preview directly
  • If you dislike them, ask to “regenerate with …”
  • Add notes like “make it more minimal, more dark theme”

Step 3: Drop the images into code

Section titled “Step 3: Drop the images into code”

From most reviews, people pick between two styles: ([Medium][9])

  1. Let the agent edit code directly

    • The agent saves images to the project’s static assets
    • It updates <img> or Image components in your React/Vue/Next.js pages

  2. Pick images yourself + tweak UI

    • Manually select a preferred image
    • Adjust layout, copy, and styles yourself

Some even used it to build a “UI + imagery” for an image-optimization tool, treating Antigravity as a graphics co-pilot. ([Enchanter Consulting][10])

V. Don’t Forget Quotas and Safety: Enjoy the Speed, Mind the Brakes

Section titled “V. Don’t Forget Quotas and Safety: Enjoy the Speed, Mind the Brakes”

1) Free image generation has limits

Section titled “1) Free image generation has limits”

Lately, Google and OpenAI have been quietly tightening free quotas:

  • Free calls for Gemini 3 Pro and Nano Banana Pro are shrinking
  • Free users only get a few image generations per day—roughly 2–3 ([TechRadar][11])

Meaning:

  • Spamming image generation in Antigravity will hit quotas
  • Good enough for product demos/internal reviews
  • For real production-scale assets, you’ll want paid plans or other tools

2) Agents inside an IDE demand respect for permissions

Section titled “2) Agents inside an IDE demand respect for permissions”

Security researchers noted that Antigravity’s “agents can run terminal commands and access files” design carries risks, such as: ([TechRadar][12])

  • Prompt injection leading agents to run odd commands
  • Accidentally exposing .env or sensitive logs
  • Overly broad permissions could even delete files

Not directly about images, but:

If you’re letting it edit code, move files, and run scripts, double-check permission settings. The image magic is cool—just don’t “draw” your servers away.

VI. Final Thoughts: With an “In-IDE Artist,” Where Would You Use It?

Section titled “VI. Final Thoughts: With an “In-IDE Artist,” Where Would You Use It?”

In one sentence:

Antigravity upgrades “AI that can code” into “a whole team of agents that can code, draw, and run a browser.”

For product builders, frontend devs, and indie makers, the value is threefold:

  • Faster MVPs and demos
  • UI/visuals and code no longer live on separate tracks
  • Solo projects feel like working with a small team

Where would you use built-in image generation?

  • Internal demos for reviews?
  • Side-project landing pages?
  • Or as a low-cost “design buddy”?

Share your thoughts in the comments—or pass this to the frontend/product/indie folks around you to try the new workflow.

item.title: 2025 Concierge Guide: Step-by-Step Applying for a Google Developer Account (with D-U-N-S / Payment Tips)
item.content:encoded:
[Intro] As domestic mobile internet traffic peaks, “going overseas” has become a must for many developers. As the world’s largest Android app distribution platform, Google Play is naturally the first stop.

However, since 2024 Google has enforced unprecedentedly strict reviews for developer accounts. Many people get stuck during registration: an unqualified network environment leading to instant bans, delays with the D-U-N-S number application, or even failing to pay the $25 fee.

Today we break down the three most critical steps to registering a Google Play developer account so you can start your global journey smoothly.

First Gate: A Stable “Network Environment” (Network)

Section titled “First Gate: A Stable “Network Environment” (Network)”

— The first firewall against account linkage

The biggest misconception for newcomers is: “as long as I can open Google, I’m good.” Completely wrong!

Google’s risk control is powerful; it tracks your IP address, device fingerprint, and browser cookies. For developer registration, “can access” is the baseline—“clean and stable” is the core.

💡 Pitfall Avoidance Guide:

  1. A fixed IP matters: During registration (and later console logins), keep your IP as static as possible. If your IP hops from the US to Singapore and back, Google will flag the account as risky or compromised, leading to bans or failed verification.
  2. Browser isolation: Use Chrome Incognito or create a dedicated browser profile for registration. Never sign in to multiple different developer accounts in the same browser; if one gets hit, cookie linkage can trigger “collective punishment.”
  3. Physical environment: If possible, operate on a clean computer that has never been used to register Google accounts.

⚠️ Warning: The purity of your network environment directly determines your account’s survival rate. Many “instant bans” happen because the IP is already on a blacklist.

Second Gate: D-U-N-S Number

Section titled “Second Gate: D-U-N-S Number”

— The global ID card for corporate identity

Since late 2023, Google Play has required “organization/company” accounts to provide a D-U-N-S Number. This has become the biggest hurdle for many small teams.

What is a D-U-N-S Number? It is a 9-digit identifier assigned by Dun & Bradstreet to recognize businesses globally. Simply put, it proves your company is real.

🛠️ Application Playbook:

  1. Prepare documents: Your business license and its English translation (the English company name must be standard, as it will show in the Google Play developer info), company seal, and contact details.
  2. Application channels:
    • Recommended: Use the Google-provided link or the Apple Developer Support page to enter the D-U-N-S application portal. These big-tech partner channels are typically faster than applying directly on the Dun & Bradstreet site and are often free.
  3. Timeline expectations: After submission, it usually takes 5–14 business days. Once you receive the number, database sync to Google may take up to 48 hours before you can enter it in the Google Play console.

📝 Key Point: The English company name and address used for the D-U-N-S application must match exactly with what you enter in Google Play. Even a single letter mismatch can cause verification failure.

Third Gate: Paying the Registration Fee (Payment)

Section titled “Third Gate: Paying the Registration Fee (Payment)”

— The $25 ticket

Unlike Apple Developer’s $99/year subscription, Google Play charges a one-time $25 (about ¥180 RMB) registration fee.

Sounds easy? Many developers still stumble at “payment failed.”

💳 Payment challenges and fixes:

  1. Card types: Google Play does not support Alipay or WeChat Pay. You need a credit card that supports foreign currency, typically Visa or MasterCard.
  2. Issuing country vs. account region: Google checks whether the card’s issuing country matches the account registration country and current IP location.
    • For a China-region developer account (using a Chinese business license), domestic Visa/MasterCard dual-currency cards usually work.
    • For an overseas account (e.g., US), do not use a domestic Chinese card—use a card from that country, or risk tripping risk controls.
  3. Billing address: When entering card info, fill the billing address truthfully.

💡 Tip: If payment keeps failing, don’t spam retries—this triggers fraud protection. Contact the issuing bank to confirm overseas card-not-present transactions are enabled, or try another card the next day.

Wrap-Up and Next Steps

Section titled “Wrap-Up and Next Steps”

Once you’ve secured a clean network environment, obtained your D-U-N-S Number, and successfully paid $25, congrats—you’ve completed 90% of the hard work!

Next, finish identity verification (upload ID/passport) and meet the latest 20-person closed test requirement (for individual accounts), and you’re ready to publish apps.

Official reference:
To stay accurate, read Google’s latest guide before you start:
Register for a Google Play developer account — Play Console Help

Wishing you smooth global expansion and one hit after another! 🚀

[Discussion] What potholes have you hit while registering a Google Play account? Drop a comment to share! 👇

item.title: Anthropic Internal AI Development Survey: Frontend Shines, Architecture Is Hardest to Hand Off to AI
item.content:encoded:
Introduction: Is AI Really Making Engineers More Productive?

Section titled “Introduction: Is AI Really Making Engineers More Productive?”

This year, every developer friend around me keeps asking the same question:

“I use Claude/Copilot every day, but is it really worth it? Are the vendors overselling me?”

Coincidentally, Anthropic turned the real usage data of 132 internal engineers and researchers into a detailed survey and interviews, plus several charts.

It is like an AI vendor giving itself a physical exam. Who is delighted, who is stumbling—everything is written in the numbers.

Let’s look at the report from a working engineer’s perspective and talk about: In software engineering, which tasks have the highest ROI with AI, and which ones should you not rush to offload to a model?

I. What Kind of Internal Survey Is This?

Section titled “I. What Kind of Internal Survey Is This?”

Anthropic asked 132 engineers and researchers a series of very concrete questions:

  • How much of your daily work do you do with Claude?
  • What do you mainly use it for? Debugging, new features, refactoring, tests, documentation, or design and planning?
  • For each task type, does working with Claude make you spend more or less time?
  • Does the volume of output (code, docs, deliverables) go up or down?

They also compared changes over time:
